Considering the environmental concern and public legislation, the current focus has been shifted to utilizing renewable resources to produce valuable chemicals. Here in, we synthesized a series of Ba-Y zeolite catalysts by incorporating different amounts of Ba (2-7 wt.%) into H-Y zeolite via an ion-exchanged method and subsequently studied these catalysts for the selective bio-ethanol conversion to ethylene. The synthesized catalysts were characterized in detail using PXRD, FTIR, NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD, Pyridine IR, BET, ICP-OES, XPS, TEM, SEM-EDX, UV-Vis, 27Al-NMR, and TGA. The catalytic conversion was executed by using 50-95 % bio-ethanol feed in a fixed bed flow reactor. The prepared Ba-Y catalysts had improved catalytic performance in relation to the parent Y zeolite within the range (200 – 350 °C). The maximum ethylene yield of >98 % was achieved at low reaction temperature of 280 °C and 10 g/ml/min contact time with 5 wt.% incorporation of Ba in HY catalyst after 15 h TOS. The modification in acidic sites of the H-Y zeolites catalyst by Ba addition is responsible for the high conversion and selectivity, controlling the side reactions and improved anti-coke capacity. Introduction Ethylene is the most significant commodity chemical used for polymer synthesis, accounting for 62 % of total raw materials used for polymer manufacturing [1,2]. Worldwide ethylene production is presently more than 140 MMT annually. It is mainly produced from fossil petroleum crude, eventually impacting the environment with greenhouse gases [3]. The increasing greenhouse gas emissions, stringent environmental legislation, and sustainability challenges have altered the focus to work on alternate renewable resources for commodity chemical production [4]. Biomass, a ubiquitous and renewable resource, serves as a prominent alternative to conventional resources. The biomass comprises starchy and crop wastes, forest product waste, aquatic plants, and municipal home wastes. These starches and cellulose-rich biomass can be fermented to bioethanol and eventually to ethylene via catalytic dehydration [5,6,7,8,9]. Numerous solid-based acid catalysts have been prepared, tested, and reported for ethanol transformation to ethylene via catalytic dehydration [10,11,12,13]. One of the earliest catalysts employed since the sixties for the ethanol-to-ethylene process is γ-Alumina (Al2O3) [14,15]. Xian et al. reported a total ethanol conversion of 90.1 % over γ-Al2O3 catalyst but at an increased reaction temperature of 475 °C. Moreso, the catalyst exhibited poor stability as it recorded 25 % decrease in ethylene yield after 80 h on stream [12]. In another work, γ-Al2O3 was doped with TiO2 for better activity. High ethanol conversion and ethylene selectivity were obtained but at >400 °C [16]. Other solid-based acid catalysts- zeolites and heteropoly acids, were later developed and studied. Zeolites have a good catalyzing ability; however, issues surrounding the deactivation of the catalyst via carbon deposition have not been fully addressed. The metal modification of these zeolites post-treatments enhance catalyst stability and reduces coke deposition [17,18,19]. H-ZSM-5 (MFI – type) zeolite catalysts have been at the forefront of most studies, but their strong acidity limits the overall performances [20,21]. Apart from H-ZSM-5 catalysts, other zeolites have also been studied for ethanol dehydration. For instance, to obtain ethylene, modified zeolite-L was explored for ethanol catalytic dehydration. The catalyst was reported to give 96 % ethylene yield at 280°C; however, a low space velocity (1.7 h-1) was required [22]. Likewise, HZSM-11 zeolites were also studied and had significantly higher stability. However, the main disadvantages of using these types of catalysts are lower selectivity to light paraffin and high reaction temperature (>350 °C) [23]. Zeolite Y faujasite molecular sieve with Si/Al ratios >2.2, diameter pores of 7.4 Å, and a three-dimensional pore structure has primary application for catalytic petroleum cracking into gasoline range hydrocarbons. However, the zeolite is also ideal for bio-ethanol dehydration considering its specific well-shaped configuration, strong acidity, and favorable open pore, effectively paving the way for acid-catalyzed reactions [24,25,26,27]. From previous works, Takahara et al. obtained an ethylene yield of 71.3 % at 1 h TOS with H-Y 5.5 zeolites, which was 28.6 % less active than other zeolites. The low activity was caused by the low amount of strong acid sites in the H-Y [28]. In 2016, the Si/Al ratio effect on catalytic dehydration of absolute ethanol to ethylene was investigated at 400-500 °C. The Si/Al ratio directly influences the catalytic activity. The low Si/Al ratios were observed to give low ethylene yield while, in contrast, high Si/Al (80/1) had the best catalytic performance with 72 % ethylene yield. However, a high reaction temperature and low ethanol conversion are major drawbacks [29]. Further, H-Y (80) catalyst modified with phosphoric acid was tested for improving the catalyst performance. Interestingly, the non-modified H-Y (80) had better catalytic activity than the modified catalysts, as the modified catalysts suffered a decrease in activity due to reduced surface area and pore from high P loadings [30]. Recently, Xia et al. worked on converting bioethanol to light olefins and reported an ethylene yield (>90) over H-Y (5.6) catalyst but 400 °C and 50 % ethanol concentration is necessary [31]. Alkaline earth metal addition to catalyst support has been reported to improve catalyst performance [6,20,32,33,34,35]. Yoshihiro et al. [36] emphasized the importance of alkaline earth metals, particularly Barium modification to zeolite, as they control acid sites and pore sizes. In this work, we evaluated the activity of zeolite Y (Si/Al=6) for bio-ethanol dehydration to green ethylene. Further, a series of Ba-Y was successfully prepared by ion exchange method for the first time and tested for improved catalytic performance over neat Zeolite Y. We also compared the catalytic performances of other metals (Mg, Sr) of Group 2A, which were also exchanged into zeolite Y from their respective metal source for the catalytic dehydration of bioethanol as compared to the best Ba-Y zeolite under the same reaction conditions. Experimental section Chemicals Zeolite Y, H-Y (Si/Al= 6) was purchased from Sud-Chemie India Pvt Ltd., India. Absolute ethanol was purchased from Fischer India. Barium chloride dihydrate (BaCl2.2H2O) was purchased from RFCL, India. Strontium nitrate [Sr(NO3)2] was supplied from Merck, Germany, and AR grade magnesium nitrate hexahydrate [Mg(NO3)2.6H2O] was procured from SRL, India. The deionized water was utilized for catalyst preparation. Catalysts preparation The commercial H-Y zeolite was first calcined to remove the template under static air at 500 °C, 1 °C/min heating rate for 5 h. The calcined H-Y zeolite is designated as HY. Series of Ba-Y catalysts were prepared by ion exchange method, which requires long hours of meticulous stirring a suspension of a calculated amount of HY in an appropriate aqueous solution of BaCl2.2H2O followed by centrifuging, drying, and calcining. For the 5 wt.% Ba-Y, 12.0 g of HY was dissolved into 0.02 M aqueous solutions of BaCl2.2H2O. The resulting mixture was subjected to continuous stirring at 50°C for 12 h. Subsequently, the solids were recovered by several washing and centrifugation and dried overnight at 120°C. Finally, the catalyst was calcined at 500°C, 1°C/min heating rate for 5 h. The prepared catalyst is denoted as 5-Ba-Y. Similarly, 2 wt.% Ba-Y and 7 wt.% Ba-Y were also prepared from the procedure as above-mentioned, with 0.01M and 0.03M of BaCl2.2H2O, respectively, used in the ion exchange process. They are finally designated as 2-Ba-Y and 7-Ba-Y, respectively. Likewise, 5 wt.%Sr-Y and 5 wt. =%Mg-Y catalysts were prepared by dissolving 12.0 g of the HY into appropriate metal salts aqueous solutions 0.04M Sr(NO3)2 and 0.14 M Mg(NO3)2.6H2O by following the same catalyst preparation as mentioned earlier. The prepared catalysts were denoted 5-Sr-Y and 5-Mg-Y, respectively. The prepared catalysts were well crushed and pelletized into 20-30 mesh sizes before being loaded into the reactor. Catalyst characterizations The characterization details including PXRD, FTIR, NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD, Pyridine IR, BET, ICP-OES, XPS TEM, SEM-EDX, UV-Vis, 27Al-NMR, and TGA are given in supporting information (SI) Catalytic activity test The prepared catalysts activities were examined for bio-ethanol conversion to bio-ethylene using a tubular fixed-bed reactor. A reactor with a cylindrical-shaped stainless steel length of 125 mm and an internal diameter of 8 mm equipped with a preheater, HPLC pump, thermocouple, split tubular furnace, and a gas-liquid separator was utilized for the reaction (S1). The reaction was performed in a gas phase to minimize diffusional limitations inside the zeolite pores in comparison with the case of performing the reaction in the liquid phase. First, a blank reaction was conducted without loading any catalyst, and no ethanol conversion was observed. For each reaction run, the reactor was loaded with 2 g (20-30 mesh size) of the catalyst and 8 g silicon carbide - a diluent, then put into the electrically fired split tubular furnace. The K-type thermocouples meticulously monitored the reaction temperature. The effects of the reaction temperature (200-350 °C), feed concentration (50-95 wt.% bioethanol), and contact time (2.8-20 g/mL/min) on the bio-ethanol conversion and selectivity of ethylene were evaluated. Before the reaction, the loaded catalyst was first preheated at 400°C under flowing nitrogen of 40 mL/min for 2 h. The bio-ethanol feed was injected into the experimental setup via an HPLC pump with an initial contact time of 10 g/mL/min. The gaseous products were identified and confirmed utilizing an online gas chromatograph (Perkin Elmar Clarus 690) merged with a flame ionization detector (FID), thermal conductivity detector (TCD), molecular sieve column, and RT-Alumina BOND column (30 m x 0.53 mm ID). Argon carrier gas flow of 20 ml/min was used. The condensates via the GLS were analyzed after 1 h reaction interval using Perkin Elmar Clarus 690 gas chromatograph with FID and HP PLOT Q column (30 m x 0.32 mm ID). The contact time was calculated by dividing the weight of the catalyst (W in g) with an ethanol set flow rate (F in mL/min). The calculations employed for ethylene yield, ethylene selectivity, and ethanol conversion were shown below: E t h a n o l c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = m o l e s o f e t h a n o l i n i t i a l l y u s e d − m o l e s o f e t h a n o l p r e s e n t a f t e r r e a t i o n m o l e s o f e t h a n o l i n i t i a l l y u s e d x 100 E t h y l e n e s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = m o l e o f e t h y l e n e f o r m e d / m o l e o f e t h a n o l r e a c t e d x 100 E t h y l e n e y i e l d ( % ) = e t h a n o l c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) x e t h y l e n e s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) / 100 Results and discussion Characterization of catalysts BET analysis The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms by the neat HY and Ba-exchanged Y catalysts were captured to determine their surface characteristics - specific surface area and pore volume in Fig. 1 . All analyzed samples displayed IV-type isotherms with conspicuous nitrogen uptake in the P/P0 range of 0.45 to 1.0, typical of H2-type hysteresis loops of zeolite Y zeolite [37–39]. The isotherm type remains unchanged upon Barium modification. This H2-type hysteresis buttresses the mesoporosity structure of catalysts and the distinctive capillary condensation in pores. Table 1 shows the surface and textural characteristics of the catalysts as revealed from the nitrogen sorption data. The BET surface area and pore volume for neat HY were 647 m2/g and 0.3230 cm3/g, respectively, but both the BET surface area and pore volume decreased with the increase in barium amount in the HY zeolite, suggesting that the exchanged ions may have occupied available site in the HY zeolite framework thereby, reducing the pore volume and surface area. TGA analysis The thermal stability of the fresh, neat HY and Ba-Y catalysts was evaluated via the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). All analyzed catalysts displayed a single steep and similar loss of weight below 200 °C as a result of the removal of water molecules trapped inside the zeolite pores, as shown in Fig. S2. Above 200 °C, no weight loss due to catalyst decomposition was observed, confirming that prepared catalysts do not have any organic component left even above 700 °C. FTIR The vibrational spectra of the neat HY and prepared Ba-Y catalysts were determined and shown in Fig. 2 . All analyzed samples display characteristic bands associated with zeolite framework [33,40,41]. The bands around 3431 cm-1 correspond to O-H stretching vibrations of the Brønsted acid site present in zeolite pores. The bands around 1631 cm-1 are ascribed to the O-H bending vibrations of the water molecules trapped inside the zeolite pores. A broad peak around 1052 cm-1 depicts the asymmetric stretching vibrations of Si-O-Si(Al) groups. The observed distinctive peaks around 811, 584, and 450 cm-1 correspond to symmetric stretching vibrations of Si-O-Si(Al) groups and bending vibrations of the external and internal O-Si(Al)-O bonds, respectively. Furthermore, there were no noticeable shifts upon incorporating Barium into the zeolite lattice, indicating that Barium only replaced the ions and did not change the lattice. Powdered X-ray diffraction (PXRD) The PXRD spectra of neat HY and Ba-Y zeolite catalysts are displayed in Fig. 3 . It was revealed that all catalysts have similar diffraction patterns typical for the Fajusite (FAU) topological structure but differing only in peak intensities [42]. The introduction of Barium into the HY framework, however, affected the peak intensity as a significant reduction in peak intensity at 2θ (degrees) = 6.4, 10.2, 12.1, 15.8, 18.9, 20.4, 23.8, 27.3, and 31.6 as Barium amount increased was observed. The similar diffraction patterns imply that incorporating Barium into the zeolite lattice had no damaging effect on the zeolite structure. Furthermore, additional peaks corresponding to the BaO for Ba-Y catalysts weren't visible on the spectra suggesting that Ba species have migrated into the zeolite Y structure and were homogenously dispersed during treatment [38]. XPS analysis The surface chemical state and composition of 5-Ba-Y catalyst were studied by XPS as shown in Fig. 4 below. Si 2p XPS spectrum shows a characteristic peak at around 101.98 eV corresponding to Si-O-Si [43]. The major peak for Al 2p XPS spectrum was found at 74.78 eV which affirms the presence of Al2O3 species [44]. O 1s spectrum shows a broad peak at 531.70 eV assigned to the Si-O-Al linkage [45]. The fitted and core-level Ba XPS spectra with doublet peaks having binding energy 779.6 eV and 794.9 eV correspond to Ba 3d5/2 and Ba 3d3/2 states respectively. The separation difference between the peak Ba 3d5/2 and Ba 3d3/2 states representing the binding energy 15.3 eV confirms that the valence state of Barium is in Ba2+ state, which agrees with literature [46,47] NH3-TPD and Pyridine-IR studies The acidity site amount and acidity strength distribution of neat HY and Ba-Y catalysts were also determined by ammonia-TPD analysis. As revealed in Fig. 5 , two desorption peaks around 100-250 °C and 300-400 °C depicting the weak and strong acid sites, respectively, were observed for all samples. This concurs with the reported literature for HY zeolite [38]. As expected, there was an apparent decrease in the strong acid sites by loosening the acid strength of HY zeolite after incorporating Barium into the zeolite lattice. The imminent barium interaction with the proton and the hydroxyl group of the zeolite may have resulted in the reduction [48]. Table 2 also displays a reduction in the total acid sites for Ba-Y zeolite, with 5-Ba-Y catalyst having the most reduction (19 %) compared to neat HY catalyst. In general, tuning the strong acid strength of the HY zeolites validates the influence of barium incorporation. Furthermore, a slight shift of peaks to lower temperatures explains the decline in the acidic strengths of the Ba-Y catalysts. Py-IR analysis was conducted to ascertain the acid types. Fig. 6 displays prominent spectra bands for HY and Ba-exchanged Y catalysts at 1443, 1489, and 1542 cm-1. The 1443 and 1542 cm-1 peaks correspond to Lewis acid and Brønsted acid, respectively. While the peak at 1489 cm-1 is attributed to the chemisorbed pyridine on both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites [49]. For 5-Ba-Y, Brønsted acid peak at 1542 cm-1 was significantly reduced upon Ba incorporation but the Lewis acid band was slightly changed compared to HY. Comparing the Ammonia TPD data (Table 2) and Py-IR profile (Fig. 6), we can deduce that barium introduction decreases the strong Brønsted acid sites, responsible for oligomerization and other side reactions. Table S1 shows the B/L ratios of the catalysts calculated using the formula reported in the literature [50], the B/L ratio is higher for HY, while a reduction is observed as the Barium is increased. We can deduce that barium introduction decreases the strong Brønsted acid sites. The CO2-TPD experiment was carried out to study the basicity of 5-Ba-Y catalyst. The results obtained are shown in Figure S7. The basicity of the catalyst influences the catalytic performance as the strong basic sites can enhance catalytic activity [51]. It can be seen from Figure S7 that the three CO2 desorption at 82°C, 203°C, and 303°C correspond to the weakly basic sites and the medium strong basic sites, and strong basic sites, respectively. The shift toward high temperature suggested that the Ba-Y catalyst possessed a strong basic concentration as corroborated by the results obtained from the experimental catalyst performance. SEM and TEM analysis The surface morphology of the samples was investigated via SEM and TEM analysis, as displayed in Fig.s 7 and Figure S3. The EDX analysis exposes the composition of elements in each catalyst along with their percentage amounts Figure S4. The SEM images for all analyzed catalysts show an agglomeration of well-organized, uniformly nanometric particles having a particle size average of ≈50 nm, typical for zeolite Y material [26,52]. Also, agglomeration increases with an increase in the exchanged Barium amount in the HY framework though the morphology was unchanged. The TEM images (200000x magnification) for all analyzed catalysts revealed a hexagonal form of zeolite Y crystals [40,53]. No major change in the structure was observed, even at a high Barium exchange amount, suggesting that metal was well dispersed during ion exchange preparation. The EDX analysis confirmed the presence of Al, Si, O for the neat HY and Al, Si, O, Ba in the Ba-Y catalysts. Moreover, there was a gradual increase in Barium amount in each of the Ba-exchanged Y catalysts prepared, depicting a successful Ba exchange in the HY zeolite catalyst. The EDX results are in concurrence with the ICP results displayed in Table 1. The elemental mapping for 5-Ba-Y catalyst with elements including Si, Al, O, and Ba is shown in Fig. 8 . This bolsters the successful incorporation of Ba into the HY lattice. UV-Vis DRS analysis The UV-Vis DRS spectra of the neat HY and the Ba-exchanged Y catalysts displayed two distinct absorbance bands at approximately 220 and 270 nm, typical of the zeolite framework [54]. Barium introduction into zeolite Y support causes a slight blue shift compared to HY zeolite, as shown in Figure S5. This depicts the influence and interaction of Barium species with the acid sites of HY. From the results, a successful preparation of Ba-Y catalysts series was achieved in concordance with the results obtained from PXRD, SEM, and BET. 27Al MAS NMR analysis We probe if there was any drastic change in the Al environment due to the catalyst modification of HY, as shown in Fig. 9 . For all analyzed catalysts, the 27Al NMR spectra showed two prominent bands at 64 and 2 ppm, attributed to the tetrahedral coordinated Al species (AlIV) and extra framework octahedral coordinated Al species (AlVI), respectively. This agrees with the reported literature [41,55,56]. The Ba-Y catalysts spectra showed a slight decrease in peak for octahedral Al species, particularly at higher Barium incorporation. Conversely, a more intense peak corresponding to tetrahedral Al species was observed for all samples. This is similar to Dolares et al.[20] work. The results showed that the zeolite framework's structure and coordination environment remain intact after Barium modification. Catalytic conversion of bioethanol Effect of reaction temperature The reaction temperature is one of the vital parameters responsible for catalytic dehydration of bio-ethanol to valuable products. We studied the ethanol conversion and ethylene selectivity dependency on reaction temperature (200-350 °C), as shown in Fig. 10 . As expected, ethanol conversion is directly related to the reaction temperature since ethanol conversion increases as temperature rises for all the catalysts. This pattern is consistent with the literature reports [57–59]. At 200 °C, the ethanol conversion for all catalysts was below 70 %, though the least conversion of 55 % was found for neat HY catalyst at that temperature. The overall ethanol conversion increases to 85-90 % for Ba-exchanged catalysts, also with ethylene selectivity at almost 100 % at 240 °C. The neat HY had the lowest conversion of 70 % at 240 °C, but the ethylene selectivity was almost 100 %. Further increase in temperature to 280 °C brought the ethanol conversion close to 100 % without compromising the ethylene selectivity. The ethanol conversion and ethylene yield were unchanged at approximately 100 % from 300-350°C for all catalysts. The total selectivity of other gaseous products, such as methane, ethane, C3, and C4, was in trace amounts (<2 %) up to 350°C. The maximum ethanol conversion, ethylene selectivity, and ethylene yield were achieved at 280°C. Effect of contact time The effect of contact time (2.8-20 g/mL/min) on bio-ethanol conversion and ethylene selectivity was examined using the 5-Ba-Y catalyst at 280 °C, and results are revealed in Fig. 11 . As expected, the ethanol conversion decreases at a lower contact time and higher at a higher contact time. A similar trend was found in literature [3,60,61]. Since at high contact time, there is a sufficient amount of time for the 95 % ethanol feed to react with the active sites of the catalyst; therefore, a high ethanol conversion is inevitable. Conversely, a low contact time will lead to partial ethanol conversion. The ethanol conversion was below 90 % from 4.0 g/mL/min below, while the highest conversion was recorded at 20 g/mL/min. Furthermore, there was a slight increase in ethylene selectivity as contact time increased from 2.8-20 g/mL/min. The optimum ethylene selectivity (≈ 100 %) was obtained at 10 g/mL/min. In contrast, Xia et al. reported a decrease in ethylene selectivity as contact time increased, resulting from a high reaction temperature of 400°C utilized for the reaction leading to higher hydrocarbons formation [62]. A moderate temperature of 280 °C favors the high ethylene selectivity in this study. Effect of feed concentration Bioethanol is a mixture of ethanol and water, and it is primarily obtained from the fermentation of biomass. However, the formation of binary azeotropic systems by ethanol and water has made conventional distillation highly energy intensive and challenging to produce high-purity ethanol >95 %. Therefore, a more environmental friendly approach of using hydrous ethanol to produce green ethylene has been employed in recent studies [63]. Different feed concentration of bioethanol (50 – 95 %) was prepared and tested for catalytic dehydration to ethylene at 280°C and 10 g/ml/min contact time using 5-Ba-Y catalyst, and the outcomes are displayed in Table 3 . From our findings, the ethanol conversion was almost 100 % for all feed concentrations examined after 3 h TOS. Interestingly, there was no significant change in conversion after 8 h for all feed concentrations. Likewise, the ethylene yield was also within 97-99 % after 8 h TOS for all feed concentrations. Our results agree with some past works - Schulz et al. reported that water shouldn't affect product selectivity since it was removed during the catalytic dehydration process [64]. Likewise, Ramesh et al. reported no observable changes in both ethanol conversion and ethylene selectivity using aqueous ethanol mixtures ranging between 10-100 % with 7.43P-ZSM-5 catalysts at 400°C [65]. The conversion of ethanol/water mixtures and ethylene selectivity were relatively insensitive in this study. Stability of the catalysts and catalyst regeneration The neat HY and Ba- exchanged Y catalysts were tested at 280°C, contact time of 10 g/ml/min, and 95 % ethanol feed. The influence of Barium exchanged into the HY catalyst on the ethanol conversion, ethylene selectivity, and ethylene yield is also reported in Table 4 and Fig. 12 . Soh et al.[66] previously reported that Si/Al ratios had a direct effect on zeolite Y activity. HY catalysts with high Si/Al ratios (Si/Al = 80) was projected as the best compared to lower Si/Al ratios. However, the ethanol conversion obtained with high Si/Al was only 73.33 % at 400°C on 1 h TOS. In contrast, in our study, neat HY (Si/Al = 6) catalyst has an ethanol conversion close to 98 % and an ethylene yield close to 95 % after 6 h TOS at a moderately low temperature of 280°C. The introduction of Barium improves the catalytic stability and performance of the zeolite catalysts. We obtained an ethanol conversion and ethylene yield of 99 % and 98.5 %, respectively after 15 h TOS for 5-Ba-Y catalyst. This performance may be attributed to the controlled acidity achieved by incorporating sufficient amount of Barium metal into the HY lattice. Other series of Ba-Y catalysts - 2-Ba-Y and 7-Ba-Y also had better activity performances than HY catalyst after 15 h TOS. The ethanol conversion and ethylene yield were 97 % and 96.5 %, respectively, for 2-Ba-Y catalyst and 98 % and 97.6 % respectively, for 7-Ba-Y catalyst. The best catalyst in the series – 5-Ba-Y, was further tested beyond 15 h run, as shown in Fig. 13 . There was a slight decline in ethanol conversion as we approached 20 h run with a 1 % loss in conversion recorded. The catalyst was subjected to regeneration under flowing air at 400 °C for 3 h to restore its activity. The activity and stability of the regenerated catalyst were then evaluated under the same reaction conditions as the fresh catalyst. From our findings, the ethanol conversion and ethylene yield were 99 % and 99 %, respectively, after another 20 h TOS. The performance of the catalyst was more impressive compared to those published previously on HY zeolite catalysts (Table 5). Comparing the catalytic performance of 5-Ba-Y catalyst with other metals in Group 2A (Mg, Sr) incorporated into HY zeolite A comparative study was performed with Ba-Y, Sr-Y, and Mg-Y at optimized reaction conditions. Interestingly, we observed that the ethanol conversion for Ba-Y, Mg-Y, and Sr-Y was close to 100 % after 1 h run, as shown in Fig. 14 . Furthermore, there was no significant change in activity after 12 h for Ba-Y and Sr-Y, but a slight decrease in activity to 98 % was recorded for Mg-Y. At 20 h TOS, the activity observed was Ba-Y>Mg-Y>Sr-Y. The ethylene yield also followed a similar pattern Ba-Y>Mg-Y>Sr-Y after 20 h run. The proposed mechanism for ethanol dehydration using barium-exchanged zeolite Y (Scheme S1) involves the adsorption of ethanol, activation of ethanol molecules via protonation, and then the dehydration to form ethylene. The Bronsted acid proton migrates to the O atom of ethanol, and one H atom of ethanol bonds with the neighboring electronegative skeleton O atom of the zeolite Y. Ethoxy groups will proceed with β-H elimination to form ethylene, followed by the recovery of the active sites [43]. Characterization of spent catalysts TGA analysis The TGA analysis was performed on the spent catalysts to know the amount of coke formed during the catalytic process. Fig. 15 reveals the amount of coke deposited on neat HY and Ba-Y catalysts after 15 h TOS as analyzed by TGA under an air atmosphere. Evidently, from the Table 6 and TGA graph, weight loss is dependent on temperature. Two conspicuous weight losses were observed. First, weight loss below 200 °C is assigned to the loss of physically absorbed water trapped inside the zeolite pores; then, above 400 °C is a result of coke calcination [67].The weight loss below 200 °C is less than 12 % for all catalysts. However, above 400 °C, the observed weight loss for HY, 2-Ba-Y, 5-Ba-Y, and 7-Ba-Y catalysts was 20.5 %, 17.3 %, 6.5 %, and 10.8 %, respectively. Less coke deposition and total weight loss were recorded for the spent Ba-Y catalyst with respect to the spent HY. The high anti-coking advantage exhibited by 5-Ba-Y catalyst over HY catalyst further explains the role of Barium in achieving high catalytic performance. Compared to Ammonia TPD results, the amount of strong acid sites reduced on incorporating Barium, making the catalyst less susceptible to coke deposition. Since coke formation is aided by the catalyst strength and acid site amounts, Barium addition tunes this acidity character to achieve better catalyst performance. Furthermore, 7-Ba-Y catalyst having more strong acid sites than 5-Ba-Y catalyst explains the higher coke deposition recorded over 5-Ba-Y. XRD analysis The XRD of the best catalyst – 5-Ba-Y catalyst was carried out after 15 h TOS and the result is shown below (Fig. 16 ). We found out that the structure was still intact after 15 h on stream as we observed all characteristics peaks at 2θ = 6.25°, 10.19°, 11.96°, 15.72°, 18.76°, 20.44°, and 23.73°, indicating that the basic faujasite structure of the zeolite Y was not affected for the fresh and spent catalysts. We calculated the crystallinity index and found it to be 81 % for both fresh and spent catalysts. However, the reduction in XRD diffraction peak intensity for the spent 5-Ba-Y catalyst could be attributed to carbon deposits on the catalysts [68]. SEM analysis SEM analysis was performed on spent HY and Ba-Y catalysts after 15 h on stream at 280 °C and 10 g/ml/min contact time. The morphology of all spent catalysts remains unchanged, as shown in Figure S6. However, there were signs of coke formation during ethanol dehydration observed on the SEM images in the form of black/dark coloration. Conclusion A series of Ba-exchanged Y catalysts were successfully prepared and tested for catalytic dehydration of ethanol to ethylene at a moderate reaction temperature of 280°C and contact time of 10 g/ml/min. Barium incorporated into zeolite Y significantly influenced the overall performance and stability of the catalyst with a high ethylene yield of >98 % and ethanol conversion of 99 % obtained for 5 wt.% Ba-Y zeolite catalyst at 15 h TOS better than reported works on the zeolite Y use for ethanol dehydration. Further, 5 wt.% Ba-Y zeolite catalyst exhibited a better anti-coking advantage over neat HY catalyst on TGA analysis as 6.5 % coke deposition was detected compared to neat HY (20.5 %). From the Ammonia TPD and Py-IR results, the amount of strong acid sites was effectively reduced on incorporating Barium, making the catalyst less susceptible to coke deposition and consequently improving the catalyst performance and stability. The morphology of the catalysts was unaffected, suggesting that the ion-exchange was effective as the metal was well dispersed during preparation. The result clearly shows that Ba-Y zeolite catalyst zeolite catalyst is effective for the selective dehydration of bio based ethanol to ethylene. coredata.dc:description: Considering the environmental concern and public legislation, the current focus has been shifted to utilizing renewable resources to produce valuable chemicals. Here in, we synthesized a series of Ba-Y zeolite catalysts by incorporating different amounts of Ba (2-7 wt.%) into H-Y zeolite via an ion-exchanged method and subsequently studied these catalysts for the selective bio-ethanol conversion to ethylene. The synthesized catalysts were characterized in detail using PXRD, FTIR, NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD, Pyridine IR, BET, ICP-OES, XPS, TEM, SEM-EDX, UV-Vis, 27Al-NMR, and TGA. The catalytic conversion was executed by using 50-95 % bio-ethanol feed in a fixed bed flow reactor. The prepared Ba-Y catalysts had improved catalytic performance in relation to the parent Y zeolite within the range (200 – 350 °C). The maximum ethylene yield of >98 % was achieved at low reaction temperature of 280 °C and 10 g/ml/min contact time with 5 wt.% incorporation of Ba in HY catalyst after 15 h TOS. The modification in acidic sites of the H-Y zeolites catalyst by Ba addition is responsible for the high conversion and selectivity, controlling the side reactions and improved anti-coke capacity.
